comments_since_last_sample.body: When my only gaming time came between Midnight and 3am (or however long I wanted to stay up, but still have to work).  Not enough time to push Nightmare level on anything anymore - and simply didn't care. I wanted to enjoy a game AND finish it.
Once it becomes annoying hard and not fun hard.
Cyberpunk 2077 is just too clunky for me to play on anything higher than normal
When I couldn't beat darkeater Midir. So I just went back to sim City instead
Weirdly I've started turning the difficulty up more these days. Whether it's years of soulsborne or what I don't know.

Call of duty 4 modern warfare. Completed the game on veteran obtaining all the achievements. Left gaming for a number of years. Got married had 3 kids. Decided to get back into gaming.... Picked up COD, couldn't get past the first level on Vet. Sold my console. Brought a PC. Now play casual RTS games

Last Valkyrie on God of War. The only time I have ever turned down the difficulty to beat a boss. I played on hard mode and I just could not beat the last one. I've beaten sekiro and all the other souls games but that valkyrie on hard is just insane for me.

I got so mad with that thing that I switched difficulty down to easy to destroy it.
The only time I turn down the difficulty is when I'm just learning a fighting game, and even then once I learn it I turn the difficulty up.

I've actually finally began turning up the difficulty on games, nothing crazy. I always used to play on the easiest setting since I wanted to just enjoy it. Now I enjoy a slight challenge, and will try most games on normal difficulty.
38yo here, play all my gaming titles on HARD
Never

I still try and judge everything on normal.  

I did put Gravity Rush 2 on Easy at the penultimate fight and was tempted to do the same at the end of The Last of Us for the same reason. I hit the point where I was no longer interested in the gameplay and I just wanted to see the ending.

I was having a conversation with a friend the other day about how I own multiple God of War games that I've never even played because I knew I wanted them, but I refused to play them out of order and I was stuck on a fight in the second one. He suggested maybe I should turn the difficulty down to which my immediate reaction was how lame that would be. After dwelling on it longer and now seeing this thread I realize how stupid the situation is, and how clearly I should get over myself and just enjoy the games, even if some of it needs to be turned down.

When I was a kid, I turned down the difficulty in Street Fighter II (when I figured out it had difficulty settings lol) because I had a ton of trouble beating the bosses. And guess what? No ending lol. You had to play at default difficulty to get the endings. So, from thereon, I've only ever checked the difficulty to make sure it's on default, or to slightly increase it in case the game was too easy/would not give the best ending.     

I've still not reached the point of lowering the difficulty. There's nothing wrong with it, and I don't look down on others for doing so, but... I feel like I'm missing out on something if I decrease the difficulty from the default. Like, this wasn't how the game was meant to be played. It's got nothing to do with pride, honestly. I know I can't keep up with the young fellas' anymore, but I do want to experience the game as it was meant to be.
My career

One day, I got home from work; I ate something, had some coffee, showered, and went for some gaming before bed. I don't even remember what I played then, I think it was “Mass Effect” or something, and I was stuck at some fight that I just couldn't win. Been stuck there for a couple of evenings already. Then I just didn't care anymore. Yeah, I wanted to beat this damn fight on the hardest difficulty, but far more than this gratification I wanted to know how the story progressed. It was at that point that I realised that after a day at work and after doing all chores, I just didn't care for a “challenge” anymore—I just want to enjoy a good story.

I've not looked back since.

Probably around my early 30s, I started to shift my focus on self achievements rather than game achievements.
I no longer had desire to 100% a game when I wanted to commit more time to personal improvement on things that will matter long term, like career and health.
I am too damn stubborn to do it, even if it takes me 20 hours i will not turn it down.
A while back. In my 30s sometime. I realized I’d rather enjoy a game than have an aneurysm. Watched a friend play through Dark Souls and throw a controller, and this guy NEVER rages.
Once I had kids. I just don’t the ability to devote the same amount of time I did before on a game. It’s more of a casual gaming experience nowadays.
